body.p: The use of error sum of squares to measure the loss of information that occurs when observations are clustered describes what linkage method?

input.choice: Ward's Method.
Centroid Linkage Method.
Single Linkage Method.
Average Linkage Method.

feedback.p: Correct: The ESS is used to measure the loss of information
Incorrect: The ESS is used to measure the loss of information for Ward's method.
Incorrect: The ESS is used to measure the loss of information for Ward's method and not single linkage.
Incorrect: The ESS is used to measure the loss of information for Ward's method and not the average linkage method.

body.p: You are classifying the topic labels of a math problem based on its text; the topic labels are from the common core standards (a US based standard for K-12 education). An example of one of the problems could be "a rectangular garden has an area of 20 square foot and width of 4 feet; what is its height?" The corresponding label would be "Rectangle Area". As a starting point, you have attempted bag-of-word features into logistic regression and your model has a good performance (95%+ F-1 score). Your colleague has asked why your model has performed so well. Which is a reasonable response below:

input.choice: The model performed well because the label is already included in the features.
The model performed well because bag-of-word and logistic regression typically go together, and they can achieve good performance in text labeling problems.
The model performed well because you have paid attention to pre-processing your data and it is performing as expected.
The model performed well because text labeling problems can usually be solved with sufficient training data.

feedback.p: Correct: There is a one-to-one mapping between the feature and the label. The algorithm is cheating in this case. It is not learning anything because most math questions have the labels in their question e.g. "find the area of or find the sum of...you can tell these are Area problems, Addition or Sum problems etc.

Incorrect:In this case, there is one to one mapping between feature and label. This will cause your model to perform well but really it is not learning anything. It is not learning anything because most math questions have the labels in their question e.g. "find the area of or find the sum of...you can tell these are Area problems, Addition or Sum problems etc.

Incorrect:In this case, there is one to one mapping between feature and label. This will cause your model to perform well but really it is not learning anything. It is not learning anything because most math questions have the labels in their question e.g. "find the area of or find the sum of...you can tell these are Area problems, Addition or Sum problems etc.
Incorrect:This will cause your model to perform well but really it is not learning anything.

body.p: Using the simple mean imputation strategy, what value would be placed in the missing observation in A:

feedback.p: Correct: The correct answer is derived by calculating the sum of all values in column A and then dividing by n in A.
Incorrect: This solution means you calculated the averages for B.
Incorrect: This solution means you summed both variables.
Incorrect: This solution means will not produce the average of variable A.

body.p: You are analyzing a benefits data set for your employer. This dataset contains two (2) variables, Job Title and Pension Benefits that are of importance to you at this moment. You find that the variable, Pension Benefits contains the five (5) types of accounts that employers can elect-into (i.e. they select one of these accounts for their pension benefits). It is mandatory for each employee to have an account. It is clear to you that you need to transform Pension Benefits to enable you analyze the dataset. Which option below would be the best way to transform this variable:

input.choice: Transform Pension Benefits by creating four (4) dummy variables.
Transform Pension Benefits by creating two (2) dummy variables.
Transform Pension Benefits by creating ten (10) dummy variables.
Transform Pension Benefits by creating three (3) dummy variables.

feedback.p: Correct: You will create dummy variables by subtracting 1 from k. k = 5.
Incorrect: You will create dummy variables by subtracting 1 from k. k = 5.
Incorrect: You will create dummy variables by subtracting 1 from k. k = 5.
Incorrect: You will create dummy variables by subtracting 1 from k. k = 5.

body.p: When would you generally expect the performance of a flexible statistical learning method to be better than an inflexible method (Select the best option):

input.choice: When the sample size n is extremely large, and the number of predictors p is small.
When the number of predictors is extremely large, and the number of observations is small.
When the relationship between the predictors and response is positively linear.
When the variance of the error terms, i.e. σ2=Var(ϵ), is extremely high.

feedback.p: Correct: A large number of observations (and low dimensionality) mean that a flexible method could capture more complex relationships without a high chance of overfitting.
Incorrect: High dimension & low observation datasets, flexible methods are at a higher risk of finding spurious relationships with the response (i.e. overfitting) and will likely underperform.
Incorrect: A flexible method would be able to and be better suited to capture non-linear relationships with the response.
Incorrect: You would expect a flexible method to perform worse, as it can find relationships between the response and the large irreducible error that a less flexible method would not.

body.p: Refer to the image below: What type of linkage method is displayed in the agglomerative clustering algorithm:

input.choice: Single Linkage Method.
Average Linkage Method.
Centroid Linkage Method.
Ward's Method.

feedback.p: Correct: This method will combine clusters that contain the closest pairs and will sometimes produce long thin clusters.
Incorrect: The Single Linkage method will combine clusters that contain the closest pairs and will sometimes produce long thin clusters.
Incorrect: The Single Linkage method will combine clusters that contain the closest pairs and will sometimes produce long thin clusters.
Incorrect: The Single Linkage method will combine clusters that contain the closest pairs and will sometimes produce long thin clusters.

body.p: You are reviewing product sales for Caribou Coffee's latest product offering. The product has four (4) variations, selling in six (6) regions across North America. You want to provide a color-scaled chart using percentage by type and location. This will clearly show where each variation is selling best and in which regions. What chart/visualization type would be the best to use among the options below:

input.choice: Heat map.
Pie charts.
Box plot.
Stacked column chart.

feedback.p: Correct: It is best used to highlight magnitude of a phenomenon. Among all the options, this option would be the most visually pleasing.
Incorrect: This sometimes useful often overused visualization is not the best to use in this situation. With more variations added, the pie chart can become very confusing to read.
Incorrect: The box plot will not show what you would like to, it will only depict the numerical data through quartiles.
Incorrect: This is useful for showing comparisons over time but it is not the best option for this scenario.

body.p: A study was conducted and the least squares estimates were based on 348 sample observations. The total sum of squares (SST) and regression sum of squares (SSR) were found to be: SST = 3.25 and SSR = 2.41. What is the error sum of squares:

feedback.p: Correct: This is the sum of squared difference between each observation and its group mean.
Incorrect: Please reassess how the SSE was computed.
Incorrect: Please reassess how the SSE was computed.
Incorrect: Please reassess how the SSE was computed.

body.p: Refer to the table below, it contains the results of a bed sheet thread count study with durability and feel as features of the dataset. Choice can be described as a customer's preference/selection (choice). The fabrics company is adding a new product to its line up with Durability = 3 and Feel = 4. What is the k-nearest neighbors when k = 2:

input.choice: Types 2 and 4
Types 1 and 4.
Types 2 and 3.
Types 3 and 4.

feedback.p: Correct: Based on the Euclidean distance of: Type 1 = ((4 − 3)2 + (2 − 4)2 = 5); Type 2 = 2; Type 3 = 4; Type 4 = 1, the ranking from lowest to highest distance is Type: 4, 2, 3, 1. k = 2 would reflect Types 2 & 4.

Incorrect: Based on the Euclidean distance of: Type 1 = ((4 − 3)2 + (2 − 4)2 = 5); Type 2 = 2; Type 3 = 4; Type 4 = 1, the ranking from lowest to highest distance is Type: 4, 2, 3, 1. k = 2 would reflect Types 2 & 4.

Incorrect: Based on the Euclidean distance of: Type 1 = ((4 − 3)2 + (2 − 4)2 = 5); Type 2 = 2; Type 3 = 4; Type 4 = 1, the ranking from lowest to highest distance is Type: 4, 2, 3, 1. k = 2 would reflect Types 2 & 4.

Incorrect: Based on the Euclidean distance of: Type 1 = ((4 − 3)2 + (2 − 4)2 = 5); Type 2 = 2; Type 3 = 4; Type 4 = 1, the ranking from lowest to highest distance is Type: 4, 2, 3, 1. k = 2 would reflect Types 2 & 4.

body.p: What would be the coefficient of determination, if Sum of Squares Error = 100 and Sum of Squares Regression = 250.

feedback.p: Correct: You will calculate the r-squared or CoE as 1-(SSE/SST) or SSR/SST
Incorrect: You will calculate the r-squared or CoE as 1-(SSE/SST) or SSR/SST
Incorrect: You will calculate the r-squared or CoE as 1-(SSE/SST) or SSR/SST
Incorrect: You will calculate the r-squared or CoE as 1-(SSE/SST) or SSR/SST

body.p: Which statement below is true about the Bias-Variance tradeoff:

input.choice: The irreducible error depends on your choice of model.
Unbiased models (models whose Bias is 0) always have the lowest prediction error.
We should always choose a predictor that has the highest bias.
The Test MSE depends on your choice of model.

feedback.p: Incorrect: This statement is tempting to select but the irreducible error does not depend on your choice of model. There are usually factors out of your control.
Incorrect: This statement is tempting to select, but this is not always the case. The Test MSE depends on your choice of model.
Incorrect: All around, we want to make sure bias is not high.
Correct: This is the right option. The test mse does depend on the choice of your model. You can not say it will be low based on a specific type of model.

body.p: Which of the following statements is true about cross-validation:

input.choice: Leave-one-out cross-validation can be considered a special case of k-fold cross-validation.
Leave-one-out cross-validation often overestimates the test error rate in comparison to a resampling method like the validation set approach.
k-fold cross-validation has higher variance than leave-one-out-cross-validation when k < n.
None of the cross validation techniques suffers from variance issues.

feedback.p: Correct: With LOOCV, k = n.
Incorrect: The reverse is the case in this situation. Validation set approach will overestimate the test error rate.
Incorrect: LOOCV has a higher variance than k fold cross validation.
Incorrect: There are ways to mitigate the issues but LOOCV has higher variance when there is high degree of correlation in training set.

body.p: Consider the statements below, which is the best description of the Principal Component Analysis (PCA):

input.choice: The transformation of a large number of correlated variables into a smaller number of uncorrelated variables.
The transformation of a small set of correlated variables into larger uncorrelated subsets.
A technique that can only be used in supervised learning and assumes that each input variable has the same variance.
A dimension reduction technique that is used when the observed variables are linear combinations of estimated latent factors.

feedback.p: Correct: This is an attribute of the PCA dimensionality reduction technique.
Incorrect: This definition might mean that you are infact increasing the dimensionality of your data.
Incorrect: This definition can can be applied to Linear Discriminant Analysis.
Incorrect: This definition is beyond the scope of the course but the technique you would be using in this case is called Factor Analysis. Watch out for it in your learning course!

body.p: You are analyzing a data set containing multiple variables with various scales. What can you do to reduce or eliminate the difference in scale in these variables:

input.choice: Perform standardization to rescale the variables within a similar range.
Calculate the Euclidean distance to rescale the variables.
Calculate the Manhattan distance to rescale the variables.
Those variables are not useful and should be eliminated or ignored.

feedback.p: Correct: This is the technique you must perform to standardize your variables.
Incorrect: This would assume that all variables can be used to calculate the euclidean distance. This options makes too many assumptions. It is best to have selected another option.

Incorrect: This would assume that all variables can be used to calculate the manhattan distance. This options makes too many assumptions. It is best to have selected another option. Also, the outcome does not give scaled results to all variables.
Incorrect: There are techniques to make the data useable before you consider ignoring or eliminating.

body.p: You learned about model performance that can be used for for regression, classification or clustering tasks. Which metric below is used to compare the performance of different regression models when you do not want to penalize large prediction errors:

input.choice: Adjusted R2.
Root Mean Square Error.
Mean Square Error.
Mean Absolute Error.

feedback.p: Incorrect: This is the average distance between each data point and the mean, it shows the variability in the dataset.
Incorrect: This is the standard deviation of the residuals (prediction errors).
Incorrect: It measures the average of the squares of the errors (difference between the estimated and actual values.) It penalizes errors
Correct: This is a measure of errors between paired observations expressing the same phenomenon and does not penalize errors like the MSE.

body.p: You have conducted an analysis on potential increase in the membership levels of current basic level memberships at a wholesale business. Refer to the ROC curve below with AUC = 0.9453. What does the AUC tell us about the model and its prediction on increased membership enrollment among current base members:

input.choice: The high AUC indicates the model performs well and better than the baseline model.
The high AUC indicates an anomaly as it requires data smoothing to match the baseline.
The high AUC indicates that the model is not predicting the level increase based on the baseline model.
The high AUC indicates there is a 0.05% probability that the model performs as predicted.

feedback.p: Correct: The model is considered a strong predictor and better than the baseline model in terms of sensitivity and specificity across all cutoff values.
Incorrect: The model is considered a strong predictor and better than the baseline model in terms of sensitivity and specificity across all cutoff values.
Incorrect: The model is considered a strong predictor and better than the baseline model in terms of sensitivity and specificity across all cutoff values.
Incorrect: The model is considered a strong predictor and better than the baseline model in terms of sensitivity and specificity across all cutoff values.

body.p: You have trained a model and the model performance metrics from the training data are considerably higher (i.e it is performing significantly better on the training dataset). When compared to the test set, the metrics tell a different story. It is performing much worse. what could be the issue:

input.choice: You have an issue of overfitting.
You have an issue of underfitting.
You do not have an issue, this is a balanced model.
There is high sensitivity and low specificity.

feedback.p: Correct: In this question your model is too closely fit to your training dataset and does not generalize to unseen data.
Incorrect: In this scenario, you do not have a situation were your training data performs poorly.
Incorrect: If your models performs significantly better with training data than with test data, it is not balanced.

Incorrect: This only means a classifier can correctly identify its class 1. If this option mentioned that you had high sensitivity but low specificity, you could align it to the question. As this is not mentioned, you should consider one of the other options.

body.p: You are building a regression tree that predicts the price of cars. How can you measure the impurity of the tree:

input.choice: The impurity is measured using the residual sum of squares.
The impurity is measured using the Gini index.
The impurity is measured using misclassification error.
The impurity is measured using the r-squared.

feedback.p: Correct: Impurity is measured using different techniques based on the problem type. This is the impurity measurement technique for regression problems. RSS is used to measure the amount of variance in a data set that is not explained by a regression model and for regression models can measure impurity.
Incorrect: Impurity is measured using different techniques based on the problem type. This is the impurity measurement technique for classification problems.
Incorrect: Impurity is measured using different techniques based on the problem type. This is the impurity measurement technique for classification problems.
Incorrect: Although r-squared is a performance metric, it is not the best measure of impurity (it will not give you much detail). You would need to use RSS.

body.p: Suppose you have a dataset with over 30 features and you have chosen to use a decision tree method for your task. You have encountered issues with overfitting and have decided to use another method to enhance the performance of your model. This method will not use all the features instead it will use a subset of the features. This method will also reduce correlation to improve the performance of your model. We can say that you are using which one of these methods below:

input.choice: Random Forest.
Bagging Method.
Boosting Method.
Classification Ensemble.

feedback.p: Correct: This describes the random forest method. It uses feature randomness when building trees to try to create uncorrelated forest of trees. One of its goals is to ensure that the prediction is more accurate than that of a single tree.
Incorrect: The definition in the question is an ensemble method, but it is not the bagging ensemble method
Incorrect: The definition in the question is an ensemble method, but it is not the boosting ensemble method.
Incorrect: It can be argued that classification ensemble method does not exist. There are better options to select among the solutions.

body.p: A company is seeking an analytical solution to increase customer sales. Once the company has identified current sources of data to support the analytical solution, the company is now considered:

input.choice: Data Science Ready.
Data Science Enabled.
Artificial Intelligence (AI) Ready.
Artificial Intelligence (AI) Enabled.

feedback.p: Correct: It is ready to begin exploring the data, assessing viability and readiness of the data to support the analytic objectives.
Incorrect: A preliminary analysis of the available data has not been conducted to ensure it supports the analytic objectives.
Incorrect: The company has not determined how to incorporate AI into its workflows.
Incorrect: The company has not deployed its analytic solution!

content.p: Using the image below, answer the following questions:

caption.p: Refer to this chart to answer the following two (2) questions.

body.p: Refer to the chart, if your goal is to compare the Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4 values across groups, which chart is better used:

input.choice: Stacked bar chart.
Grouped bar chart.
Both charts shown.
None of the charts shown.

feedback.p: Correct: You have considered the task at hand and selected the right visualization.
Incorrect: Although useful, it is not the chart type for this scenario, always consider the perceptual task involved when picking a visualization.
Incorrect: One of the chart types is useful, always consider the perceptual task involved when picking a visualization.
Incorrect: One of the chart types is useful, always consider the perceptual task involved when picking a visualization.

hint.p: consider the perceptual task in this question please.

body.p: Refer to the chart, If the goal is to compare the Q1, Q2, Q3, and Q4 values within groups, which chart is best used:

input.choice: Grouped bar chart.
Stacked bar chart.
None of the chart options.
Both of the chart options.

feedback.p: Correct: This chart option will do a good job in showing the perception of position among a common scale.
Incorrect: Although useful, it is not the chart type for this scenario, always consider the perceptual task involved when picking a visualization.
Incorrect: One of the options be suited for this scenario, always consider the perceptual task involved when picking a visualization.
Incorrect: Both would not be suited for this scenario, always consider the perceptual task involved when picking a visualization.

body.p: You are interested in predicting the percent (%) change in the US Dollar in relation to the weekly changes in the stock markets. Hence, you have gathered weekly data for all of 2005. For each week, you record the % change in the USD/Euro, the % change in the US market, the % change in the British market, and the % change in the German market. Which statement below is true about this scenario.

input.choice: This is a regression problem and you will be mainly concerned with making predictions.
This is a regression problem and you will be mainly concerned with inference.
This is a classification problem and you will be mainly concerned with inference.
This is a classification problem and you will be mainly concerned with prediction.

feedback.p: Correct: You are not interested in how the predictors relate with your response variable.
Incorrect: You are not interested in how the predictors relate with your response variable.
Incorrect: This is not a classification problem, the percentage change in $ is continuous and not categorical. You are also concerned with prediction and not inference.
Incorrect: This is not a classification problem, the percentage change in $ is continuous and not categorical.

body.p: Based on the average predictions of a group of analysts, South Africa's gross domestic product (GDP) will expand by 2.3% in 2020. Suppose the sample standard deviation of their predictions was 2%. At the 10% significance level, you have tested if the mean forecast GDP of all analysts is less than 3%. What is the null and alternative hypothesis (Choose the most suitable answer):

feedback.p: Correct: This is the correct solution.
Incorrect: Consider that this option is highlighting the opposite of what the null and alternative hypothesis state in the scenario.
Incorrect: The null and alternative hypothesis state otherwise. H0: μ ≥ 3; HA: μ < 3 .
Incorrect: The null and alternative hypothesis state otherwise. H0: μ ≥ 3; HA: μ < 3 .

body.p: Based on the average predictions of a group of analysts, South Africa's gross domestic product (GDP) will expand by 2.3% in 2020. Suppose the sample standard deviation of their predictions was 2%. The calculated value of the t-statistic = -2.3479. You have found that 0.01≤ p-value < 0.025. At the 10% significance level, can we conclude that the mean forecast GDP of all analysts is less than 3%

input.choice: Yes, since we reject H0.
Yes, since we fail to reject H0.
No, since we reject H0.
All options listed are not accurate.

feedback.p: Correct: Since the p-value < α = 0.10, we reject H0. At the 10% significance level, we conclude that the mean forecast of all analysts is less than 3%.
Incorrect: Since the p-value < α = 0.10, we reject H0. At the 10% significance level, we conclude that the mean forecast of all analysts is less than 3%. We can not fail to reject
Incorrect: Since the p-value < α = 0.10, we reject H0. At the 10% significance level, we conclude that the mean forecast of all analysts is less than 3%.
Incorrect: Since the p-value < α = 0.10, we reject H0. At the 10% significance level, we conclude that the mean forecast of all analysts is less than 3%.

body.p: You have created a document term matrix of a twitter dataset, you are treating each tweet as one document. Consider frequency of terms that occur in a collection of the documents, which statement below is true:

input.choice: Normalization of words in the data will increase the dimensionality of data .
Removal of stopwords from the data will affect the dimensionality of data .
Converting all the words in lowercase will not affect the dimensionality of the data .
Removal of stopwords from the data will not affect the dimensionality of data .

feedback.p: Incorrect: Normalization of words will decrease dimensionality and reduce redundancy in the features.
Correct: It will decrease the number of features.
Incorrect: Doing this will affect the dimensionality by decreasing it.
Incorrect: Removal of stopwords will affect dimensionality, it decreases the number of features..

body.p: Suppose that you have a dataset with 3500 observations and 135 predictors. After much work, you have selected a model and would like to estimate its prediction error. You run a 5-fold cross-validation and get an error estimate of 210.2. The Senior Analyst on your team checks your outcome by running a 5-fold cross-validation as well, will they get the exact same error estimate as you did?

input.choice: No, the Senior Analyst's error estimate may be different.
Yes, the Senior Analyst will surely receive the exact same estimate as yours.
Yes, the Senior Analyst will surely receive an estimate higher than yours.
Yes, the Senior Analyst will surely receive an estimate lower than yours.

feedback.p: Correct: k-fold CV requires randomly splitting the data into k parts. They should windup with a different random split, and thus a somewhat different error estimate.
Incorrect: k-fold CV requires randomly splitting the data into k parts. They will windup with a different random split, and thus a somewhat different error estimate.
Incorrect: k-fold CV requires randomly splitting the data into k parts. They will windup with a different random split, and thus a somewhat different error estimate.
Incorrect: k-fold CV requires randomly splitting the data into k parts. They will windup with a different random split, and thus a somewhat different error estimate.

content.p: You have been hired by a clothing retailer specializing in the sales of men's high end fashion for less. The target market for this company includes anyone between the ages of 18 and 45. The company uses social media to market its products. You are developing predictive models that will help the company increase sales and also acquire new customers based on a promotional campaign drive. The table shown in the next question is the confusion matrix. Class 0 is the group of social media users (also followers of the business social media pages) who will not make a purchase after receiving promotional messages from your client. Class 1 is the group that will purchase one product or more within 30 days of receiving the aforementioned promotional message.
Answer the following questions based on this scenario:

body.p: How would you interpret the confusion matrix based on the scenario:

input.choice: There are 29 customers who have purchased and are correctly classified as buyers by the classifier and 133 customers were classified correctly as individuals who did not make a purchase. However, 19 customers were classified as buyers when they have not made a purchase and 19 customers were classified as non-buyers when they have actually made purchases.

There are 133 customers who have purchased and are correctly classified as buyers by the classifier and 19 customers were classified correctly as individuals who did not make a purchase. However, 29 customers were classified as buyers when they have not made a purchase and 19 customers were classified as non-buyers when they have actually made purchases.

There are 29 customers who have purchased and are correctly classified as buyers by the classifier and 133 customers were classified correctly as individuals who did not make a purchase. However, 29 customers were classified as buyers when they have not made a purchase and 19 customers were classified as non-buyers when they have actually made purchases.

There are 133 customers who have purchased and are correctly classified as buyers by the classifier and 29 customers were classified correctly as individuals who did not make a purchase. However, 19 customers were classified as buyers when they have not made a purchase and 133 customers were classified as non-buyers when they have actually made purchases.

feedback.p: Correct: You have interpreted the confusion matrix properly.
Incorrect: You have interpreted the confusion matrix wrongly. The TP is 29, TN= 133, FP =19 and FN =19.
Incorrect: You have interpreted the confusion matrix wrongly. The TP is 29, TN= 133, FP =19 and FN =19.
Incorrect: You have interpreted the confusion matrix wrongly. The TP is 29, TN= 133, FP =19 and FN =19.

body.p: Calculate and interpret the sensitivity and specificity from the scenario (figures are not rounded):

input.choice: The classifier was able to correctly identify 60.4% of buyers and correctly identify 87.5% of non-buyers.
The classifier was able to correctly identify 87.5% of buyers and correctly identify 60.4% of non-buyers.
The classifier was able to correctly identify 71% of buyers and correctly identify 81% of non-buyers.
The classifier was able to correctly identify 81% of buyers and correctly identify 87.5% of non-buyers.

feedback.p: Correct: You have calculated and interpreted both correctly! sensitivity should be 29/(29+19) and specificity as 133/(133+19)

Incorrect: You have calculated the sensitivity as the specificity and the specificity as the sensitivity. These numbers are not correct, your formula for sensitivity should be 29/(29+19) and specificity as 133/(133+19)
Incorrect: These numbers are not correct, your formula for sensitivity should be 29/(29+19) and specificity as 133/(133+19)
Incorrect: These numbers are not correct, your formula for sensitivity should be 29/(29+19) and specificity as 133/(133+19)

body.p: Calculate and interpret the accuracy rate from the scenario:

input.choice: The accuracy rate is 0.81, which implies that 81% of the observations in the dataset were classified correctly.
The accuracy rate is 0.875, which implies that 87.5% of the observations in the dataset were classified correctly.
The accuracy rate is 0.41, which implies that 41% of the observations in the dataset were classified correctly.
The accuracy rate is 0.78, which implies that 78% of the observations in the dataset were classified correctly.

feedback.p: Correct: You have interpreted and calculated the accuracy correctly.
Incorrect: You should have calculated accuracy as TP+TN/(TP+TN+FP+FN)
Incorrect: You should have calculated accuracy as TP+TN/(TP+TN+FP+FN)
Incorrect: You should have calculated accuracy as TP+TN/(TP+TN+FP+FN)
